item.title: Temporal Single-Node Reliability Deep Dive: How It Survives Server Crashes, Network Failures, and Rollback Errors
item.description: Writing business logic with Temporal is pure joy — “code like a single-machine program, get distributed fault tolerance for free.” But after the honeymoon phase, a nagging question remains: Is it really reliable? What if the Server crashes? What about network partitions? What if the rollback itself fails? This article tears apart these questions from the ground up.

item.title: Dive into K8s 02: Cilium Replaces Flannel — Goodbye VXLAN Tax, Hello eBPF Native Networking
item.description: Last post, we hand-rolled Flannel in Kind cluster and witnessed the 50-byte per-packet VXLAN encapsulation overhead via tcpdump. This time, we replace Flannel with Cilium, leveraging eBPF to completely eliminate this “network tax”, and use Hubble for traffic visualization.

item.title: Dive into K8s: Hand-Rolling CNI with Kind, From CrashLoop to VXLAN Packet Capture
item.description: This weekend, I built a “networkless” cluster from scratch on Manjaro using kind, manually debugged missing kernel modules and CNI plugins, and finally witnessed the VXLAN encapsulation process with tcpdump. This post documents the entire journey.

item.title: Temporal vs K8s Controller: Declarative vs Imperative Control Plane Paradigms
item.description: K8s Controllers and Temporal are both “control plane” technologies, but they represent fundamentally different design philosophies. This post deep-dives into their core differences and explores how to combine them in AI Infra platforms.

item.title: Temporal in Practice: From Saga Pattern to Self-Healing Distributed Transactions
item.description: While building a trading system backend, I used Temporal to solve the classic distributed transaction consistency problem. This post breaks down Temporal’s core mechanisms and explores its applications in AI task scheduling.

item.title: Postmortem: Debugging a Zookeeper Split-Brain in Production
item.description: One night at 2 AM, Kafka message lag alerts fired. Investigation revealed a Zookeeper cluster split-brain — two nodes both thought they were the Leader. This post documents the full debugging and recovery process.

item.title: Go Microservices War Stories: 5 Lessons from Dependency Management to Service Discovery
item.description: Microservices isn’t just about splitting up a monolith. This post documents 5 real pitfalls I hit in Go microservices projects, and how to avoid them.
